elements.content: Reactions of (4-amino-1-hydroxybutylidine)-1,1-bisphosphonic acid (alendronic acid = LH5) with 1 equiv of the group 1 metal bases KOH, KHCO3, Rb2CO3, RbOH, or Cs2CO3 in aqueous solution at pH 4–5 gave the corresponding complexes [M­(LH4)­(H2O) n ]·m(H2O), M = K (1), Rb (2), or Cs (3). Crystallization of the products under varying conditions yielded differing hydrates and/or polymorphic phases. Rapid crystallization of the potassium complex 1 from water/EtOH or water/DMSO gave 2­[K­(LH4)]­·3­(H2O) (1a), whereas slow crystallization from water or water/DMSO gave [K2(LH4)2­(H2O)2]­·2H2O (1b phase I). For the rubidium complex 2, rapid crystallization from water/EtOH gave the analogous [Rb2(LH4)2­(H2O)2]­·2H2O (2b phase I), whereas slow crystallization from water/DMSO also gave 2b, but as a mixture of phase I and the structural polymorph [Rb­(LH4)­(H2O)]­·H2O (2b phase II). In contrast, only [Cs­(LH4)­(H2O)]­·H2O (3b phase II) was obtained for the cesium complex 3 under all crystallization conditions. A second complex type [M­(LH4)­(LH5)]­·2H2O (M = Rb 4, Cs 5), incorporating an additional coordinated alendronic acid molecule, was also observed for the larger metals Rb and Cs as a minor product in some syntheses and isolated by fractional crystallization for 4, but as the sole product from Cs­(O2CH) and LH5 for 5. The crystal structures of the complexes [M­(LH4)­(H2O) n ]·m(H2O) 1a, 2b (phase II), and 3b (phase II) comprise edge-shared or corner-shared polyhedral chains that are linked by bridging bisphosphonate ligands into two-dimensional (2-D) sheets. The 4-ammoniobutylidene chains protrude above and below the coordination layers and interact with neighboring layers through hydrogen bonding of the terminal ammonium group forming distinctive supramolecular three-dimensional (3-D) arrays. The phase I structure of 1b and 2b comprises ribbons of parallel M4(LH4)4(H2O)4 subunits arranged in a more close packed 3-D supramolecular network. For [M­(LH4)­(LH5)]­·2H2O (M = Rb 4, Cs 5), isolated M+ cations, bridged by bisphosphonate ligands, are arranged into 2-D sheets, with the pendant 4-ammoniumbutylidene chains resulting in a 3-D lamellar network similar to those of 1a and 2b/3b (phase II). All of the [M­(LH4)­(H2O) n ]·m(H2O) and [M­(LH4)­(LH5)]­·2H2O structures display strong PO–H···O­(phosphonate) and N–H···O­(phosphonate/water) hydrogen bond motifs which significantly impact the observed structures. Reactions of LH5 with 2 equiv of the group 1 metal bases MOH (M = Na, K, Rb, Cs) at pH 9–10 gave the dimetalated complexes [M2(LH3)­(H2O) n ]­·m­(H2O) (M = Na 6, K 7, Rb 8, Cs 9). Crystallization of 6 from water/MeOH gave [Na2(LH3)­(H2O)4]­·H2O (6a) as a single phase. For 7, crystallization from water/MeOH gave K2(LH3)­·3­(H2O) (7a) as the bulk product, whereas crystals of [K2(LH3)­(H2O)6] (7b) were grown from water/DMSO solutions. On standing, the crystals of 7b were converted into the bulk product 7a. The structures of 6a and 7b are chain rather than sheet bisphosphonate coordination polymers, with a high number of coordinated water molecules. Moreover, their 3-D supramolecular structures are distinguishable, viz. a pillared array for 6a and a more compact bilayer structure for 7b. The [M2(LH3)­(H2O) n ]­·m­(H2O) complexes of the larger group 1 metal cations 8 and 9 each crystallized as a mixture of phases. Crystals of [Rb2(LH3)­(H2O)5]­·(H2O) (8a) and [Cs4(LH3)2­(H2O)9]­·2­(H2O) (9a), respectively, were identified as the major component after crystallization from DMSO/H2O. The lesser hydrates [Rb4(LH3)2­(H2O)8]­·(H2O) (8b) and [Cs2(LH3)­(H2O)4] (9b) were also identified, but were not isolated as bulk materials. The structures of 8a, 8b, 9a, and 9b each were complex 2-D sheets of bisphosphonate metal coordination polymers, which assembled through supramolecular interactions into compact 3-D arrays.

elements.content: Metal organophosphonate materials have attracted considerable attention due to their rapidly evolving structural diversity and attractive applications in industrial and biomedical arenas. An important subset is the 1,1-bisphosphonates (R1)­(R2)­C­(PO­(OH)2)2 (e.g., alendronic acid, ), which are a class of pharmaceuticals currently used in the clinical treatment of bone disorders such as osteoporosis, Paget’s disease, and hypocalcemia, and are of increasing importance in bone cancer therapy. Bisphosphonates are good metal-complexing agents, a property which plays a significant role in the bioactivity of these molecules. Thus, they have a high affinity for calcium and are able to target and accumulate in bone mineral as well as interact with specific enzymes through trinuclear metal (Mg2+, Mn2+, Zn2+) coordination in the subsequent inhibition of biochemical processes. Molecules such as alendronic acid also offer a number of accessible protonation states within a reasonable pH range and a short carbon chain with a terminal ammonium group. Both these features, while critical for their biological function, also present opportunities for crystal engineering of coordination complexes through the formation of strong PO–H···O and N–H···O hydrogen bonds. Because of their pharmaceutical relevance, the formation and structures of complexes of alendronate with the Na+ and Ca2+ cations have been studied revealing both one-dimensional (1-D) and two-dimensional (2-D) coordination polymer structures. These structures also verify the development of three-dimensional (3-D) hydrogen bonded networks in these materials through interactions of the pendant cationic alkylammonium group, the phosphonate residues, and the lattice water molecules. More recently, studies of metal coordination compounds of alendronate and related 1,1-bisphosphonate ligands have led to new strategies for their use in the treatment of cancer and other medicinal applications, as well as developing new materials with magnetic, photochromic, and electrocatalytic properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal organophosphonate materials have attracted considerable attention due to their rapidly evolving structural diversity and attractive applications in industrial and biomedical arenas. An important subset is the 1,1-bisphosphonates (R1)(R2)C(PO(OH)2)2 (e.g., alendronic acid, ), which are a class of pharmaceuticals currently used in the clinical treatment of bone disorders such as osteoporosis, Paget's disease, and hypocalcemia, and are of increasing importance in bone cancer therapy. Bisphosphonates are good metal-complexing agents, a property which plays a significant role in the bioactivity of these molecules. Thus, they have a high affinity for calcium and are able to target and accumulate in bone mineral as well as interact with specific enzymes through trinuclear metal (Mg2+, Mn2+, Zn2+) coordination in the subsequent inhibition of biochemical processes. Molecules such as alendronic acid also offer a number of accessible protonation states within a reasonable pH range and a short carbon chain with a terminal ammonium group. Both these features, while critical for their biological function, also present opportunities for crystal engineering of coordination complexes through the formation of strong PO-H⋅⋅⋅O and N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds. Because of their pharmaceutical relevance, the formation and structures of complexes of alendronate with the Na+ and Ca2+ cations have been studied revealing both one-dimensional (1-D) and two-dimensional (2-D) coordination polymer structures. These structures also verify the development of three-dimensional (3-D) hydrogen bonded networks in these materials through interactions of the pendant cationic alkylammonium group, the phosphonate residues, and the lattice water molecules. More recently, studies of metal coordination compounds of alendronate and related 1,1-bisphosphonate ligands have led to new strategies for their use in the treatment of cancer and other medicinal applications, as well as developing new materials with magnetic, photochromic, and electrocatalytic properties.

Mole ratios LH5:M Crystallization conditions: (a) H2O/EtOH, (b) H2O/DMSO, (c) H2O/evaporation, (d) H2O/MeOH, (e) air, (f) minor product.

In this current contribution we have investigated the syntheses and structures of a series of new coordination polymers of alendronic acid (LH5, ) with a particular focus on cations from the group 1 metals potassium, rubidium, and cesium. As described above, the multimetal binding capabilities of the bisphosphonate group should be well suited to these large oxophilic cations (K–Cs ionic radii are ca. 0.36–0.65 Å greater than for Na at CN = 6) which generally exhibit more indiscriminate coordination environments in terms of coordination numbers (typically 6–10), irregular geometries, and a wider range of bond distances than the smaller group 1 metals lithium and sodium. For example, the reported crystal structures of the alendronate complexes [Li­(LH4)­(H2O)2], [Na­(LH4)­(H2O)]­·2­(H2O), and [Na­(LH4)] show fairly typical four-coordinate tetrahedral Li+ or six-coordinate octahedral Na+ environments. Furthermore, in the absence of a distinct metal–ligand topology for M = K–Cs, the interligand hydrogen bonding interactions may also become more significant and potentially structure-determining. With this in mind, two pH regimes were also investigated, one at pH 4–5 promoting the presence of alendronate as LH4 – and possessing at least two residual strong PO–H hydrogen bond donors, and the second at higher pH values, removing one of the PO–H moieties giving LH3 2– while simultaneously increasing the ratio of metal/ligand and the available metal coordination sites. We now report the synthesis and structural characterization of three classes of group 1 metal complexes of alendronic acid: (i) [M­(LH4)­(H2O) n ]·m(H2O) (M = K 1, Rb 2, Cs 3), (ii) [M­(LH4)­(LH5)]­·2­(H2O) (M = Rb 4, Cs 5), and (iii) [M2(LH3)­(H2O) n ]·m(H2O) (M = Na 6, K 7, Rb 8, Cs 9). Crystallization of complexes in classes (i) and (iii) under differing conditions revealed a rich structural chemistry complemented by the observation of multiple phases comprising structural polymorphs or differing hydrates for many of the products. This crystalline diversity provides a challenge in engineering conditions to give single pure phases.

In this current contribution we have investigated the syntheses and structures of a series of new coordination polymers of alendronic acid (LH5, ) with a particular focus on cations from the group 1 metals potassium, rubidium, and cesium. As described above, the multimetal binding capabilities of the bisphosphonate group should be well suited to these large oxophilic cations (K-Cs ionic radii are ca. 0.36-0.65 Å greater than for Na at CN = 6) which generally exhibit more indiscriminate coordination environments in terms of coordination numbers (typically 6-10), irregular geometries, and a wider range of bond distances than the smaller group 1 metals lithium and sodium. For example, the reported crystal structures of the alendronate complexes [Li(LH4)(H2O)2], [Na(LH4)(H2O)]⋅2(H2O), and [Na(LH4)] show fairly typical four-coordinate tetrahedral Li+ or six-coordinate octahedral Na+ environments. Furthermore, in the absence of a distinct metal-ligand topology for M = K-Cs, the interligand hydrogen bonding interactions may also become more significant and potentially structure-determining. With this in mind, two pH regimes were also investigated, one at pH 4-5 promoting the presence of alendronate as LH4 - and possessing at least two residual strong PO-H hydrogen bond donors, and the second at higher pH values, removing one of the PO-H moieties giving LH3 2- while simultaneously increasing the ratio of metal/ligand and the available metal coordination sites. We now report the synthesis and structural characterization of three classes of group 1 metal complexes of alendronic acid: (i) [M(LH4)(H2O) n ]⋅m(H2O) (M = K 1, Rb 2, Cs 3), (ii) [M(LH4)(LH5)]⋅2(H2O) (M = Rb 4, Cs 5), and (iii) [M2(LH3)(H2O) n ]⋅m(H2O) (M = Na 6, K 7, Rb 8, Cs 9). Crystallization of complexes in classes (i) and (iii) under differing conditions revealed a rich structural chemistry complemented by the observation of multiple phases comprising structural polymorphs or differing hydrates for many of the products. This crystalline diversity provides a challenge in engineering conditions to give single pure phases.

elements.content: Alendronic acid monohydrate was generously provided by the pharmaceutical company GenRX Pty Ltd. and was used as received. The group 1 metal salts were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich or Strem Chemicals and used as received or made up as standardized solutions in water. IR spectra in the region 4000–650 cm–1 were recorded for finely ground powdered samples using an Agilent Cary 630 ATR instrument with ResPro data handling software. Medium or greater intensity absorptions are listed for the region 1250–650 cm–1; full spectra are shown in the Supporing Information (S4.1–S4.10). NMR measurements were obtained for solutions in D2O on a Bruker DPX400 operating at 400 MHz for 1H. Solid state 31P NMR spectra were obtained for powdered samples using standard cross-polarized magic-angle spinning techniques with a spin rate of 10 000 Hz on a Bruker ADVANCE 300 MHz solid state spectrometer. Chemical shifts were referenced using external TMS or NH4H2PO4 standards. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were obtained on a Mettler-Toledo TGA/DSC 1 and are listed in . Elemental analyses were performed in duplicate by the Campbell Microanalytical Laboratories, University of Otago, NZ.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General

Alendronic acid monohydrate was generously provided by the pharmaceutical company GenRX Pty Ltd. and was used as received. The group 1 metal salts were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich or Strem Chemicals and used as received or made up as standardized solutions in water. IR spectra in the region 4000-650 cm-1 were recorded for finely ground powdered samples using an Agilent Cary 630 ATR instrument with ResPro data handling software. Medium or greater intensity absorptions are listed for the region 1250-650 cm-1; full spectra are shown in the Supporing Information (S4.1-S4.10). NMR measurements were obtained for solutions in D2O on a Bruker DPX400 operating at 400 MHz for 1H. Solid state 31P NMR spectra were obtained for powdered samples using standard cross-polarized magic-angle spinning techniques with a spin rate of 10000 Hz on a Bruker ADVANCE 300 MHz solid state spectrometer. Chemical shifts were referenced using external TMS or NH4H2PO4 standards. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were obtained on a Mettler-Toledo TGA/DSC 1 and are listed in . Elemental analyses were performed in duplicate by the Campbell Microanalytical Laboratories, University of Otago, NZ.

Single crystal X-ray data were collected at 123 K using an Oxford Gemini Ultra CCD with MoKα (1a, 1b (phase II), 2b (phase II), 4, 5, 6a, 7b) or CuKα (1b (phase I), 2b (phase I), 3b (phase II), 8a, 9a) radiation. The diffraction images were processed using the CrysAlisPro software package. Suitable crystals of compounds 8b and 9b were too small for a standard laboratory X-ray diffractometer (typically <0.04 mm), and data were collected at the Australian Synchrotron. The MX1 beamline endstation comprised a ϕ goniostat with an ADSC Quantum 210r detector, and the sample temperature was 100 K. The diffraction images were collected using BlueIce and processed using the XDS software package. Because of hardware constraints, two separate collections with differing crystal orientations were performed for each crystal, and these were then merged for the final data sets to obtain >95% data coverage. All structures were solved by standard methods and refined by full matrix least-squares using the SHELX-97 program. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms attached to C were placed in calculated positions using a riding model with C–H distances of 0.99 Å and U iso(H) = 1.2 × U eq(C). The approximate positions of acidic hydrogen atoms associated with N or O were located in the difference Fourier maps (except for 1b, see below) and were included in the final refinement cycles as riding atoms with restrained N–H (0.91 Å) or O–H (0.84 Å) distances and U iso(H) = 1.5 × U eq(N/O). For water molecules the H–O–H angles were additionally restrained to ca. 109°. For 1b (phase I) several crystals were measured but were invariably twinned. The reported data are the best that was obtained and the structure solved and refined adequately with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. The results confirmed that the structure was isomorphous with that of 2b (phase I), consistent with the similarity of the solid state spectroscopic results for the two compounds (see below). For the final refinement cycles, the atom coordinates (including hydrogen atoms) from 2b were used as a starting point. The apparent twinning manifests as a number of relatively significant residual electron density peaks in chemically nonsensible positions, presumably contributing to the high R value. Attempts to resolve the twinning using either the twin data processing in CrysAlsiPro or the TwinRotMat routine in PLATON were not successful. Crystal data and refinement details are listed in , , and .

Powder X-ray diffraction data of the bulk compounds were obtained for finely ground samples using Bruker D8 FOCUS instrument (Bragg–Brentano θ-2θ geometry) with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at room temperature and processed using the Bruker DIFFRAC SUITE software v2.1. The observed patterns were compared with those generated from the single crystal data using Mercury v3.0; slight differences in the peak positions are presumed to result from the different sample temperatures (see Supporting Information, S2.1–2.10).

Aqueous solutions of 1, 2, and 3 were prepared by addition of LH5·H2O (10–100 mmol), either as a solid, or as a suspension in water, to aqueous solutions of MOH, MHCO3, or M2CO3 in a 1:1 acid to metal ratio. elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

General Syntheses of [M(LH4)(H2O) n ]⋅m(H2O) Complexes

Aqueous solutions of 1, 2, and 3 were prepared by addition of LH5⋅H2O (10-100 mmol), either as a solid, or as a suspension in water, to aqueous solutions of MOH, MHCO3, or M2CO3 in a 1:1 acid to metal ratio. When the carbonate reagents were utilized, evolution of CO2 was observed. After addition of the acid, the reaction mixtures were heated to ensure complete reaction and then cooled to room temperature. The complexes were isolated from the final solution as described below.

elements.content: EtOH (ca. 40 mL) was added to a solution of 1, prepared from LH5·H2O 27.4 g, 105 mmol, and KHCO3 10.5 g, 105 mmol in ca. 300 mL of water, resulting in the formation of a white precipitate. The mixture was then stirred at room temperature, and the solid was collected by filtration and washed with EtOH and dried to constant weight under vacuum giving 30.0 g (91%) of 2­[K­(LH4)]·3­(H2O) 1a as a white powder. IR (ν, cm–1): 1242­(m), 1150­(m), 1123­(m), 1061­(m), 1038(s), 1018(s), 948­(m), 901­(vs), 861(s), 826­(m), 756­(mbr). 1H NMR (ppm): 2.93 (m, 4H, CH2N), 1.89 (m, 8H, CH2CH2). 31P MAS NMR (ppm): 23.0 (s), 21.3(s), 15.4(s), 12.8(s). MS (positive ES, m/z): selected peaks 288 [15%, K­(LH5)+], 326 [100, K2(LH4)+], 364 [27, K3(LH3)+], 402 [2, K4(LH2)+]. Elemental analyses (%). Found: C 15.56, H 4.87, N 4.39. Calcd for C8H30K2N2O17P4: C 15.29, H 4.81, N 4.46. In an analogous synthesis, 1a was also prepared by slow addition of a solution of K2CO3 4.4 g, 32 mmol in 20 mL of water to a suspension of LH5·H2O 17.2 g, 66 mmol and in ca. 100 mL of hot water and was isolated as above giving 17.2 g (85%) of 1a (identified by PXRD). Crystals of 1a for X-ray crystallography were grown by addition of DMSO (ca. 5 mL) to a solution of 1, prepared from LH5·H2O 4.3 g, 16 mmol and KOH 16 mL of a 1.0 M solution, 16 mmol, in ca. 25 mL of water until a permanent precipitate had formed. The mixture was then heated until clear, filtered, and allowed to cool overnight resulting in a colorless crystalline mass that was collected by filtration and dried under ambient conditions giving 4.0 g (80%) of 1a. The PXRD of the bulk material was identical with that obtained for 1a above.

elements.content: DMSO (ca. 5 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of 2, prepared from LH5·H20 4.3 g, 16 mmol and Rb2CO3 1.84 g, 8.0 mmol in 20 mL, until a small amount of a permanent precipitate formed, and the resulting mixture was heated until clear and then cooled slowly to room temperature. A crystalline mass formed after several days and was collected by filtration, washed with DMSO, and dried under a vacuum giving 4.40 g (75%) of Rb­(LH4)·2­(H2O) 2b, as a mixture of phase I (major) and phase II (minor). The IR spectrum and PXRD pattern matched that of 2b (phase I) above. 31P MAS NMR (ppm): 21.1(s), 20.3 (s), 19.3(s), 18.2(s), 17.3(s), 13.3(s) ppm (see Supporting Information, Figure S3.5). Approximately 2.0 g of the product was redissolved in 40 mL of water and 5 mL of DMSO was added. The resulting mixture was filtered and allowed to stand for several days after which colorless crystals had formed which were collected by filtration and dried in air giving 1.28 g (64%) of 2b, as a mixture of phase I (minor) and phase II (major). 31P MAS NMR (ppm): 21.0(s), 20.3 (s), 19.5(s), 18.2(s), 17.3(s), 13.3(s) ppm (see Supporting Information, Figure S3.6).

On cooling to room temperature and standing overnight, colorless crystals deposited and were collected by filtration and dried under ambient conditions giving 2.2 g of LH5·H2O. The filtrate was allowed to slowly reduce in volume under ambient conditions for several days after which large colorless crystals deposited which were collected by filtration and dried under ambient conditions giving 0.50 g (10%) of [Rb­(LH4)­(LH5)]·2­(H2O) 4. elements.clean_text:
General Syntheses of [M2(LH3)(H2O) n ]⋅m(H2O) Complexes

Aqueous solutions of 6, 7, 8, and 9 were prepared by addition of LH5⋅H2O (10-100 mmol), either as a solid, or as a suspension in water, to aqueous solutions of MOH in a 1:2 acid to metal ratio. After complete addition of the acid, the reaction mixtures were heated to ensure complete reaction, and then cooled to room temperature. The measured pH values were in the range 9.0-9.5. The complexes were isolated from the final solution as described below.

elements.content: A solution of 6 (prepared from LH5.H2O 26.7 g, 100 mmol and NaOH 8.0 g, 200 mmol) in 100 mL of water was reduced in volume to ca. 20 mL and MeOH (ca. 30 mL) was added giving a white precipitate. The solid was collected by filtration, washed with MeOH, and then purified by dissolution in hot water, filtration, and reprecipitation with MeOH. The final product was collected by filtration and dried under a vacuum to constant weight giving 38.0 g (99%) of [Na2(LH3)­(H2O)4]­·H2O 6a as a white powder. IR (ν, cm–1): 1145­(m), 1108(s), 1073(s), 1016­(vs), 972(s), 943(s), 910(s), 871­(m). 1H NMR (ppm): 3.00 (t, 2H, CH 2 N), 1.93 (m, 4H, CH 2 CH 2 ). 31P MAS NMR (ppm): 21.2 (s), 20.2(s). MS (positive ES, m/z): selected peaks 272 [27%, Na­(LH5)+], 294 [55, Na2(LH4)+], 316 [31, Na3(LH3)+], 338 [9, Na4(LH2)+]. Elemental analyses (%). Found: C 12.75, H 5.43, N 3.70. Calcd for C4H21NNa2O12P2: C 12.54, H 5.52, N 3.66. Crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were grown in the mother liquor after separation of the bulk product.

elements.content: A solution of 8 (prepared from LH5.H2O 1.76 g, 6.59 mmol, and RbOH·H2O 1.74 g, 14.4 mmol) in 50 mL of water was reduced to approximately 25 mL under vacuum and then MeOH was added until incipient precipitation. The mixture was heated until clear and then cooled to 4 °C. The resulting white microcrystalline material was collected by filtration and washed with MeOH and dried in air giving 2.40 g (70%) of [Rb2(LH3)­(H2O)5]·H2O 8a as a free-flowing white powder. IR (ν, cm–1): 1167(s), 1080(s), 1053­(vs), 1027­(vs), 963­(vs), 925(s), 833­(m), 781­(mbr), 737(s), 656(s). 1H NMR (ppm): 3.00 (s, 2H, CH 2 N), 1.92 (m, 4H, CH 2 CH 2 ). 31P MAS NMR (ppm): 19.4­(d, J PP = 34 Hz), 17.9­(d, J PP = 28 Hz). Elemental analyses. Found: C 9.48, H 4.30, N 2.69. Calcd for C4H23NO13P2Rb2: C 9.13, H 4.41, N 2.66. Recystallization of a portion of the bulk product (ca. 200 mg) from DMSO/H2O (1:5) gave a mixture of colorless crystals of 8a and a small amount of a colorless oil. The latter partially crystallized on standing yielding crystals of [Rb4(LH3)2­(H2O)8]­·(H2O) 8b.

elements.content: A solution of 9 (prepared from LH5·H2O 3.54 g, 13.3 mmol and CsOH·H2O (>90% purity) 4.72 g, 25.3 mmol) in 50 mL of water was reduced to approximately 25 mL under a vacuum. MeOH was added until incipient precipitation, and then the mixture was heated and allowed to cool to room temperature and then stored at 4 °C. The resulting white precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with MeOH and dried in air giving 6.06 g (78%) of [Cs4(LH3)2­(H2O)9]­·2­(H2O) 9a as a free-flowing white powder IR (ν, cm–1): 1157(s), 1075(s), 1058(s), 1037­(vs), 1019­(vs), 967­(vs), 940­(m), 922­(m), 897­(m), 848­(m), 669­(m). 1H NMR (ppm): 3.01 (s, 4H, CH 2 N), 1.94 (m, 8H, CH 2 CH 2 ). 31P CPMAS NMR (ppm): 24.0(s), 18.8(s), 15.9(s). MS (positive ES, m/z): selected peaks 133 [100%, Cs+], 514 [2, Cs2(LH4)+]. Elemental analyses. Found: C 8.07, H 3.66, N 2.28. Calcd for C8H44Cs4N2O25P4: C 7.85, H 3.62, N 2.29. Crystals of 9a, suitable for X-ray crystallography were grown from a DMSO/H2O solution of the bulk material. Crystals of [Cs2(LH3)­(H2O)4] 9b were obtained from an analogous preparation in which the initial product had formed as an oil that partially crystallized on standing.

elements.content: Alendronic acid reacted readily with the group 1 metal bases MOH, MHCO3, or M2CO3 in water in a 1:1 metal to acid ratio to yield complexes of the form M­(LH4)·n(H2O) (M = K 1, Rb 2, Cs 3, ). The pH values of the final solutions were in the range 4–5, consistent with the presence of alendronate as LH4 –. The bulk products were initially isolated in high yield by precipitation with MeOH or EtOH (1 and 2) or by evaporation of the solution to dryness (3) which gave materials with the compositions 2­[K­(LH4)]­·3­(H2O) (1a), Rb­(LH4)­·2­(H2O) (2b), and Cs­(LH4)­·2­(H2O) (3b). Elemental analyses were in agreement with the proposed formulas and TGA data () displayed mass losses in the temperature range 120–170 °C corresponding to elimination of approximately three (1a) or two (2b, 3b) water molecules, respectively. In addition, solid state 31P MAS NMR data (see below) confirmed that each of these materials was a single phase. Crystals of 1a and 3b were grown from water/DMSO and were characterized by single crystal structure determination (see below), and the calculated PXRD pattern matched those obtained for the initially isolated bulk products (see Supporting Information, S2.1–S2.10). However, further crystallization experiments for the K and Rb complexes 1 and 2 under differing conditions revealed a more rich structural variety. Slow recrystallization of 1a from a dilute water/DMSO mixture gave colorless needles of [K2(LH4)2­(H2O)2]­·2H2O 1b. Similarly, recrystallization of a small sample of 2b from water/DMF gave a mixture of crystal types, corresponding to two structural polymorphs (herein after referred to as phase I and phase II). Both phases were characterized by single crystal structure determination with the phase I structure isomorphous with that of the K complex 1b, whereas the phase II structure is isomorphous with that of 3b. The calculated PXRD pattern for 2b (phase I) matched that obtained for the bulk isolated product, suggesting that the latter is pure phase I, and this was confirmed by the solid state 31P MAS NMR data (see below). Attempts to isolate a bulk sample of 2b (phase II) appeared to yield only mixtures of phase I and phase II in varying proportions. During the course of the crystallization experiments, crystals of a second complex type [M­(LH4)­(LH5)]­·2H2O (M = Rb 4, Cs 5) were observed in isolated instances and usually only as a minor product. A bulk sample of 4 was isolated in low yield from a reaction of Rb2CO3 and 4 equiv of LH5.H2O by fractional crystallization. In contrast, reaction of LH5·H2O with Cs­(O2CH) gave 5 in high yield, irrespective of the use of a 1:1 metal–acid ratio.

Results and Discussion

Alendronic acid reacted readily with the group 1 metal bases MOH, MHCO3, or M2CO3 in water in a 1:1 metal to acid ratio to yield complexes of the form M(LH4)⋅n(H2O) (M = K 1, Rb 2, Cs 3, ). The pH values of the final solutions were in the range 4-5, consistent with the presence of alendronate as LH4 -. The bulk products were initially isolated in high yield by precipitation with MeOH or EtOH (1 and 2) or by evaporation of the solution to dryness (3) which gave materials with the compositions 2[K(LH4)]⋅3(H2O) (1a), Rb(LH4)⋅2(H2O) (2b), and Cs(LH4)⋅2(H2O) (3b). Elemental analyses were in agreement with the proposed formulas and TGA data () displayed mass losses in the temperature range 120-170 °C corresponding to elimination of approximately three (1a) or two (2b, 3b) water molecules, respectively. In addition, solid state 31P MAS NMR data (see below) confirmed that each of these materials was a single phase. Crystals of 1a and 3b were grown from water/DMSO and were characterized by single crystal structure determination (see below), and the calculated PXRD pattern matched those obtained for the initially isolated bulk products (see Supporting Information, S2.1-S2.10). However, further crystallization experiments for the K and Rb complexes 1 and 2 under differing conditions revealed a more rich structural variety. Slow recrystallization of 1a from a dilute water/DMSO mixture gave colorless needles of [K2(LH4)2(H2O)2]⋅2H2O 1b. Similarly, recrystallization of a small sample of 2b from water/DMF gave a mixture of crystal types, corresponding to two structural polymorphs (herein after referred to as phase I and phase II). Both phases were characterized by single crystal structure determination with the phase I structure isomorphous with that of the K complex 1b, whereas the phase II structure is isomorphous with that of 3b. The calculated PXRD pattern for 2b (phase I) matched that obtained for the bulk isolated product, suggesting that the latter is pure phase I, and this was confirmed by the solid state 31P MAS NMR data (see below). Attempts to isolate a bulk sample of 2b (phase II) appeared to yield only mixtures of phase I and phase II in varying proportions. During the course of the crystallization experiments, crystals of a second complex type [M(LH4)(LH5)]⋅2H2O (M = Rb 4, Cs 5) were observed in isolated instances and usually only as a minor product. A bulk sample of 4 was isolated in low yield from a reaction of Rb2CO3 and 4 equiv of LH5.H2O by fractional crystallization. In contrast, reaction of LH5⋅H2O with Cs(O2CH) gave 5 in high yield, irrespective of the use of a 1:1 metal-acid ratio.

elements.content: The reactions of alendronic acid with the group 1 metal hydroxide salts MOH were also performed with a 1:2 acid to metal ratio to yield complexes of the form M2(LH3)·n(H2O) (M = Na 6, K 7, Rb 8, Cs 9). The final pH of the solutions prior to precipitation of the products was between 9 and 10 consistent with the presence of LH3 2–. The reaction for M = Na 6 straightforwardly gave [Na2(LH3)­(H2O)4]­·H2O (6a) in high yield after precipitation of the bulk product with MeOH. The PXRD and 31P MAS NMR data were consistent with the crystal structure (from crystals grown from the mother liquor; see below) indicating that the bulk product was a single phase material. Elemental analyses were satisfactory, and TGA data () indicated a sharp single step mass loss at 123 °C, corresponding to elimination of four water molecules. For M = K 7, the bulk product precipitated by addition of MeOH, K2(LH3)­(H2O)3 (7a) has a different composition from crystals of [K2(LH3)­(H2O)6] (7b) grown from water/DMF. The latter readily lost water on standing, and attempts to prepare a bulk sample of 7b were unsuccessful. The subsequent loss of all three water molecules from 7a was shown by TGA () to occur at a temperature well above 100 °C. Crystallization of the products for M = Rb 8 or Cs 9 from water/EtOH gave the corresponding complexes [Rb2(LH3)­(H2O)5]­·(H2O) (8a) and [Cs4(LH3)2­(H2O)9]­·2­(H2O) (9a). Crystals of both complexes were grown from water/DMSO solutions as the major component in each case. However, a second crystal form was observed in both systems and corresponded to a lesser hydrate of each complex, [Rb4(LH3)2­(H2O)8]­·(H2O) (8b) and [Cs2(LH3)­(H2O)4] (9b). The calculated PXRD patterns for 8a and 9a corresponded with those of the bulk products, and the elemental analyses and TGA data were consistent with the formula. However, spectroscopic data suggested (see below) that for 8a, the bulk material was contaminated with a little 2b (phase II).

elements.content: The metal alendronate products were characterized by solid state spectroscopic techniques. The IR spectra of the M­(LH4) complexes each display a weak broad absorption centered at approximately 3200–3000 cm–1 attributable to OH and NH stretching vibrations (see Supporting Information S4.1–S4.4). These absorptions are considerably more intense in the spectra of the corresponding M2(LH3) compounds (see Supporting Information S4.7–S4.10), presumably reflecting the higher numbers of coordinated water molecules in the latter. A complex series of absorption bands between 1250 and 1000 cm–1 was also observed in all the spectra, and these are in the typical region for P–O stretching vibrations. From the crystal structures (see below) the alendronate anion in the M­(LH4) complexes is zwitterionic, having one -NH3 + and two -PO2(OH)− groups, whereas the M2(LH3) complexes have instead one -PO3 2– and one -PO2(OH)− group. The interpretation of these P–O stretching vibrations is further complicated by the differing coordination modes of each phosphonate group in the individual complexes. However, the spectra of the M­(LH4) complexes with closely related structures, e.g., 1a, and 2b/3b (phase II), are very similar to each showing three groups of multiple absorption bands centered at ca 1150, 1050, and 900 cm–1, whereas the spectra of 1b/2b (phase I) were somewhat different showing two intense broad absorptions at ca. 1130 and 900 cm–1. The M2(LH3) complexes 6a, 7a, 8a, and 9a also have multiple P–O stretching bands similar to those of the M­(LH4) complexes with an additional strong absorption near 960 cm–1, plausibly indicative of the -PO3 2– group.

elements.content: The current M­(LH4), M­(LH4)­(LH5), and M2(LH3) complexes were also analyzed by solid state 31P MAS NMR. Data for several 1,1-bisphosphonate molecules in their acid form have shown distinguishable isotropic shifts for the -PO­(OH)2 and -PO2(OH)− sites (e.g., for LH5.H2O we observed two peaks at δ 15.5 (d, J PP 44 Hz) and 14.8 (br s) ppm, cf Lit. a 16.6 and 15.9 ppm). However, for metal complexes, the dominant influence on the isotropic 31P MAS NMR shifts is most likely to be the metal-phosphonate coordination modes, and the number of peaks generally correlates with the number of unique phosphonate sites in the corresponding crystal structure. As shown in Supporting Information Figures S3.1–3.3, the data obtained for the three structural variants 1a, 2b (phase I), and 3b (phase II) (corresponding to the bulk products) are distinctive, and the number of isotropic peaks matches the number of crystallographically unique phosphorus atoms in the relevant crystal structures. In some cases, peaks are split into doublets due to P–P coupling with J PP ≈ 30–60 Hz. The spectrum of 1a (Figure S3.1) shows four single resonances at δ 23.0, 21.3, 15.4, and 12.8 ppm corresponding to two different phosphonate groups of the two independent alendronate ligands in the structure (see below). Similarly, the spectrum of 2b (phase I) (Figure S3.2) also shows four resonances at δ 21.1, 19.5, 18.4, and 17.3 ppm, and these are very similar to those (δ 22.7, 19.9, 18.5, and 17.6 ppm, see Supporting Information, Figure S3.4) observed for the isomorphic complex 1b (phase I) that was obtained from recrystallization of 1a. In contrast, the spectrum of 3b (phase II) (Figure S3.3) shows only two peaks at δ 19.5 and 11.8 ppm consistent with the single crystallographically unique alendronate ligand. The spectra for samples of 2b from the crystallization experiments (see Supporting Information, Figure S3.5–6) show the four peaks observed for phase I with two additional peaks at δ 20.3 and 13.3 ppm corresponding to the phase II component. The spectra also show that the proportion of phase II could be enriched substantially, but we were unable to obtain a pure 2b (phase II) sample. Consistent with the above observations, the spectrum for [Cs­(LH4)­(LH5)]­·2­(H2O) 5 (see Supporting Information, Figure S3.8) shows four peaks, two for the LH5 ligand and two for the LH4 – ligand. In contrast for the analogous complex [Rb­(LH4)­(LH5)]­·2­(H2O) 4 (Figure S3.7) there are three resonances in the same chemical shift range, and presumably there is coincidental overlap of two peaks in this case. The 31P MAS NMR data for the M2(LH3) complexes (Figures S3.9–3.12) appears to be largely consistent with the observed crystal structures with complex 6a showing two peaks at δ 20.2 and 21.2 ppm (Figure S3.9) and complex 9a showing three peaks at δ 24.0, 18.8, 15.9 ppm, the latter presumably two pairs of peaks that are partially overlapped (Figure S3.12). Complex 7a, which was not structurally characterized (see below), displayed only two resonances at δ 16.8 and 24.8 ppm (both as doublets, J PP 38–40 Hz) (Figure S3.10). The data for the bulk sample of the Rb complex 8a showed two main peaks at δ 19.5 and 17.9 ppm (both as doublets, J PP 28–34 Hz), consistent with the observed structure (see below), with an additional small peak at δ 13.3 ppm (Figure S3.11). The latter is plausibly due to an impurity of [Rb­(LH4)­(H2O)]­·(H2O) 2b (phase II) (Figure S3.6) (there is a small shoulder on the δ 19.5 peak which may correspond to the 20.3 ppm peak of 2b). For the remaining two complexes 8b and 9b, we were unable to obtain sufficient amounts for NMR characterization.

elements.content: Complex 1a comprises a set of two different 2-D coordination polymer sheets of [K­(LH4)] in which each 2-D sheet contains solely one or the other of the two unique potassium atoms K(1) and K(2), with the layers alternating in the 3D structure (a). The building blocks of the 2D sheets are edge-shared polyhedral chains of K+ cations (b), propagated through pairs of bridging phosphonate groups, and successive parallel chains are connected through bridging bisphosphonate ligands. Thus, each ligand binds four K+ cations, and the metal–ligand connectivity is shown in Figure S5.1. For K(1), the bisphosphonate ligand is μ4-1κ2(O,OH)­:2κ3(OH,O′,O″)­:3κ2(OH′,O‴)­:4κ2(O‴,COH), while for K(2), the 1κ2(O,OH) and 3κ2(OH′,O‴) connections convert to unidentate by not having the K–O­(H)–P bond. Hence the coordination number is reduced from nine for K(1) to seven for K(2). The K–O bond distances (K(1) 2.603(2)–3.119(2) Å, K(2) 2.675(2)–3.001(2) Å) are in the normal range observed for analogous complexes. The change in coordination number from K(1) to K(2) is related to differences in the strong (1.67(1)–1.75(1) Å) phosphonate hydrogen bond patterns within each of the 2-D sheets. Four bisphosphonate ligands surround each K(1) or K(2) center with a change in the connectivity between two ligands from a phosphonate···water···phosphonate linkage around K(1) to a direct phosphonate···phosphonate linkage for K(2). A consequent twist in the orientation of the coordinated phosphonate groups lengthens two of the K–OH distances to nonbonding, ca. 4.0 Å. The interlayer region also shows a distinctive hydrogen bond pattern in which the 4-ammoniobutylidene chains protrude above and below the planes of metal atoms. Pairs of alendronate ligands are connected head-to-tail through N–H···phosphonate interactions in a R 2 2(16) ring motif, and this feature is ubiquitous through all the subsequent structures described below. These rings form pillars between successive potassium-bisphosphonate sheets, and the interlayer spacing is ca. 9.6 Å. Lattice water molecules occupy the vacancies between the 4-ammoniobutylidene chains and form additional hydrogen bonded bridges between the layers. Potassium complexes with related bisphosphonate ligands (e.g., [K­(L)­(H2O)]·H2O, L = RC­(OH) (PO2(OH)−)2, where R = CH2pyH+ or CH2imH+) similarly show 2-D sheet coordination polymer structures but with different metal–ligand connectivity from that of 1a. However, these structures also form layers through N–H···phosphonate hydrogen bonds in the same head-to-tail R 2 2(16) ring motif, albeit with additional π–π interactions of the parallel heterocyclic rings and a larger interlayer spacing (ca. 14.1, 13.3 Å respectively).
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

[K2(LH4)2]⋅3(H2O) 1a 

Complex 1a comprises a set of two different 2-D coordination polymer sheets of [K(LH4)] in which each 2-D sheet contains solely one or the other of the two unique potassium atoms K(1) and K(2), with the layers alternating in the 3D structure (a). The building blocks of the 2D sheets are edge-shared polyhedral chains of K+ cations (b), propagated through pairs of bridging phosphonate groups, and successive parallel chains are connected through bridging bisphosphonate ligands. Thus, each ligand binds four K+ cations, and the metal-ligand connectivity is shown in Figure S5.1. For K(1), the bisphosphonate ligand is μ4-1κ2(O,OH):2κ3(OH,O',O"):3κ2(OH',O‴):4κ2(O‴,COH), while for K(2), the 1κ2(O,OH) and 3κ2(OH',O‴) connections convert to unidentate by not having the K-O(H)-P bond. Hence the coordination number is reduced from nine for K(1) to seven for K(2). The K-O bond distances (K(1) 2.603(2)-3.119(2) Å, K(2) 2.675(2)-3.001(2) Å) are in the normal range observed for analogous complexes. The change in coordination number from K(1) to K(2) is related to differences in the strong (1.67(1)-1.75(1) Å) phosphonate hydrogen bond patterns within each of the 2-D sheets. Four bisphosphonate ligands surround each K(1) or K(2) center with a change in the connectivity between two ligands from a phosphonate⋅⋅⋅water⋅⋅⋅phosphonate linkage around K(1) to a direct phosphonate⋅⋅⋅phosphonate linkage for K(2). A consequent twist in the orientation of the coordinated phosphonate groups lengthens two of the K-OH distances to nonbonding, ca. 4.0 Å. The interlayer region also shows a distinctive hydrogen bond pattern in which the 4-ammoniobutylidene chains protrude above and below the planes of metal atoms. Pairs of alendronate ligands are connected head-to-tail through N-H⋅⋅⋅phosphonate interactions in a R 2 2(16) ring motif, and this feature is ubiquitous through all the subsequent structures described below. These rings form pillars between successive potassium-bisphosphonate sheets, and the interlayer spacing is ca. 9.6 Å. Lattice water molecules occupy the vacancies between the 4-ammoniobutylidene chains and form additional hydrogen bonded bridges between the layers. Potassium complexes with related bisphosphonate ligands (e.g., [K(L)(H2O)]⋅H2O, L = RC(OH) (PO2(OH)-)2, where R = CH2pyH+ or CH2imH+) similarly show 2-D sheet coordination polymer structures but with different metal-ligand connectivity from that of 1a. However, these structures also form layers through N-H⋅⋅⋅phosphonate hydrogen bonds in the same head-to-tail R 2 2(16) ring motif, albeit with additional π-π interactions of the parallel heterocyclic rings and a larger interlayer spacing (ca. 14.1, 13.3 Å respectively).

elements.content: The phase I structures of 1b and 2b comprise a supramolecular array of 1-D coordination polymeric ribbon-like chains (a) composed of repeating parallel tetranuclear [M2(LH4)2­(H2O)2]2 substructures (b) which are assembled into infinite chains through bridging bisphosphonate groups. There are two unique M+ sites: M(1), which lies on the edges of the polymer ribbon, and M(2) which is part of the C 2-symmetric central pair. Each M+ has a coordinated water molecule, and the four M+ centers are connected through bridging -PO2(OH) groups. The metal ligand connectivity for the two unique ligands for each structure is shown in Figure S5.2. One bisphosphonate ligand is μ3-1κ­(O)­:2κ2(O′,O″)­:3κ2(O‴,COH), while the second is μ5-1κ3(O,O′,OH)­:2κ­(O′)­:3κ2(O″,O‴)­:4κ­(O‴)­:5κ­(COH). However, analysis of the M–O bond distances shows two additional longer interactions in the 3.4–3.6 Å range for each complex, as indicated in Figure S5.2. Comparable data for group 1 metal phosphonate complexes that possess similar lamella topographies, [M­(HO3P-R-PO3H2)] R = CH2CH2, C6H4C6H4, [Rb­(HEDP)]·2­(H2O) (HEDP = MeC­(OH)­(PO3H)2) show metal–oxygen bond distances typically <3.1 Å for M = K, <3.3 Å for M = Rb and <3.5 Å for M = Cs. These suggest that significantly longer M–O distances are beyond the limit to be considered as primary coordination bonds and are more akin to weaker interactions such as metal-π-arene (K···C ca. 3.2 Å, Rb···C ca. 3.4 Å, Cs···C ca. 3.6 Å). Notably, for each of the longer M–O distances observed in 1b/2b (phase I), the metal atom is coordinated to a P–OH donor that is constrained by strong phosphonate···phosphonate hydrogen bonds (1.61(2)–1.80(2) Å) which form part of a R 3 3(10) ring motif with two further -PO2(OH) groups. Despite the formation of a 1-D chain structure in 1b/2b (phase I) rather than the 2-D sheet coordination polymer observed for 1a (and also the phase II structures of 2b and 3b below), the overall supramolecular structure has some similarities. Each ribbon is laterally connected through strong (1.72(2) Å) self-complementary phosphonate···phosphonate hydrogen bonding between pairs of equivalent -PO2(OH) groups in a R 2 2(8) ring motif resulting in a supramolecular 2-D layer. In addition, the 4-ammoniobutylidene groups protrude above and below these layers and interact with neighboring ribbons through N–H···phosphonate hydrogen bonds resulting overall in a 3-D layer-like structure with an interlayer spacing ca. 9.5 Å similar to 1a (above). However, only one of the bisphosphonate ligands exhibits the head-to-tail R 2 2(16) ring motif observed in 1a, whereas the 4-ammoniobutylidene chain of the second ligand has a bent conformation and forms instead a R 3 3(12) ring motif with a lattice water molecule and a -PO2(OH) group from a neighboring ligand.

elements.content: The second polymorphic structure of 2b and that of its heavier congener 3b are isomorphous and are similar to the structure of 1a, consisting of a supramolecular stack of 2-D coordination polymer sheets (a), with comparable metal–ligand connectivity and metal-phosphonate and alkyl chain layering. In each of the 2b/3b (phase II) structures, the sole unique metal center bonds to four symmetry related ligands and an additional water molecule. These are assembled into corner-shared polyhedral chains (b) that are slightly undulating to accommodate the coordinated water molecule (cf in 1a the chains are essentially flat as there is no coordinated water), and successive chains are bridged by the bisphosphonate ligands into a 2-D coordination polymer sheet. The unique bisphosphonate ligand in each structure is μ4-1κ­(O)­:2κ3(OH,O′,O″)­:3κ2(OH′,O‴)­:4κ2(O‴,COH), and the metal–ligand connectivity and associated bond distances are shown in Figure S5.3. However, similar to the situation in 1b/2b (phase I) above, analysis of the M–O distances shows one longer distance for each complex at ca. 3.7 Å which is not included in the bonding description, and for M = Rb one at ca. 3.4 Å which is borderline (Figure S5.3). The longer M–O distances are associated with a P–OH donor groups which are constrained by the strong phosphonate···phosphonate hydrogen-bonds (1.68(1), 1.70(1) Å 2b; 1.72 (2), 1.72(2) Å 3b). These supramolecular interactions generate an undulating network comprising a single R 4 4(20) ring motif involving four bisphosphonate ligands (a). Remarkably, this same hydrogen bond network is also observed in the structure of [Na­(LH4)­(H2O)]­·2H2O (b), for which the unit cell parameters (see Supporting Information S1) are very similar to those of 2b/3b (phase II), although the two structural types are not the same. The primary difference is the position of the metal cation binding sites. The larger rubidium and cesium cations are centrally located within the cavity of each ring and bound to four bisphosphonate ligands generating the 2-D coordination polymer sheet, whereas the smaller sodium cation is sited on the edges on the cavity and bound to only two bisphosphonate ligands forming a 1-D chain polymer. In addition to the above hydrogen bonds of 2b, 3b, N–H···phosphonate interactions bind head-to tail pairs of the alendronate ligands (see of 1a above) which protrude between the 2-D coordination polymer sheets yielding a supramolecular 3-D network, supplemented by bridging interactions of the lattice water molecules which occupy the voids between the alkyl chains (a).

elements.content: The two [M­(LH4)­(LH5)]­·2­(H2O) (M = Rb, Cs) complexes both incorporate an additional molecule of alendronic acid in the metal coordination sphere. Both structures have very similar atom connectivity, each comprising a 2-D coordination polymer sheet with the typical arrangement of the 4-ammoniobutylidine chains above and below the plane (a). For complex 4, the Rb+ cations are eight-coordinate and bridged by a μ-1κ2(O,O′)­:2κ2(O″,COH) bisphosphonate ligand and a μ-1κ2(O,OH)­:2κ2(O′,COH) alendronic acid ligand. The bonding in the Cs complex 5 is similar (b), but with the 1κ2(O,O′) connection of the LH4 – ligand converted to 1κ3(O,O′,OH), and hence the coordination number increases to nine. The M–O distances are in a relatively narrow range (2.867(2)–3.274(2) Å, M = Rb; 3.068(2)–3.431(2) Å, M = Cs) and do not show any of the longer metal–oxygen interactions as observed for the M­(LH4) complexes above. The positions of the acidic hydrogen atoms were readily located from the X-ray data for both complexes. In each structure, the LH4 – ligands, in combination with a lattice water molecule, form a hydrogen bonded square grid comprising a R 6 6(24) ring motif. The metal cations are situated approximately above the water molecules, followed by an analogous hydrogen-bonded square grid of LH5/H2O molecules (rotated by ca. 90° and offset such that the grid vertices lie over the cavities of the LH4 – layer). Apart from coordination to the metal cations, the LH4 – and LH5 ligands are also linked by strong (1.61(1)–1.78(2) Å in 4; 1.64(2)–1.72(2) Å in 5) phosphonate···phosphonate hydrogen bonding in a R 3 3(12) ring motif involving the additional P–OH acid residue of the LH5 ligand. In the interlayer region, the 4-ammoniobutylidene chains are grouped in head to tail pairs in the typical R 2 2(16) ring motif (LH5) or a slightly different R 2 2(12) ring (LH4 –), the ammonium cation binding to the OH substituent rather than the phosphonate group. The lattice water molecules also bridge between the metal phosphonate layers resulting overall in a 3-D network with an interlayer spacing of ca. 9.4 Å, similar to 1a and 2b/3b above. The detailed coordination environments are shown in Supporting Information Figure S5.4.

elements.content: The structures of the M2(LH3) complexes demonstrate the effect of increasing the amount of metal coordination space which results in significantly higher numbers of coordinated water molecules. However, the structure of the Na+ complex 6a (a) has similarities to that of [Na­(LH4)­(H2O)]­·2­(H2O), as both are 1-D coordination polymer chains with perpendicular 4-aminobutylidene groups. In 6a, the coordination polymer comprises a central chain of planar equatorial Na­(μ-O)4 units with two water molecules in the axial positions (b). Three successive Na(1) cations are bridged by a 1κ­(O)­:2κ2(O,O′)­:3κ­(O′) bisphosphonate ligand which further binds a Na(2) cation through a κ2(O,O″) interaction, O(1) and O(6). The coordination sphere of the second sodium cation is completed by four water molecules, two of which also bridge to successive Na(1) cations from the central chain. The Na(2)­(H2O)4 units are bound alternately on either side of the central chain. The overall metal–ligand connectivity and associated bond distances are shown in Figure S5.5. The hydrogen bonding network in 6a is different from that in the M­(LH4)­(H2O) n /M­(LH4)­(LH5) structures (see above) with the absence of the strong PO–H···O interactions, the sole phosphonate···phosphonate hydrogen bond is longer (1.84(1) Å) and links successive bisphosphonate groups along the length of the chain. There is an intricate hydrogen bonding network of water interactions, including O–H···O hydrogen bond bridges between the coordinated and lattice water molecules in the space between the alkyl chains (a), as well as lateral O–H···O hydrogen bonds between the coordinated water molecules and the phosphonate groups of neighboring chains. The protruding 4-ammoniobutylidine from neighboring coordination polymer chains pack in a head-to-tail fashion, albeit in a zigzag chain motif rather than the R 2 2(16) ring observed for the other alendronate complexes. Notably, the structure of the closely related complex [Na2(L′H3)­(H2O)4]­·H2O (L′H3 = H3NCH2CH2C­(OH)­(PO3H)­(PO3)2–), has a different metal–ligand connectivity and a different overall chain structure from that of 6a, despite having the same number of coordinated and lattice water molecules.

elements.content: The K+ complex 7b also presents as a coordination polymer chain structure (a) that shows several differences from that of 6a. In this case the polymer chain is comprised of pairs of edge-shared potassium polyhedra where the bisphosphonate ligand is bound to one potassium cation only, the second potassium cation being fully coordinated by six water molecules, two of which are bridging (b). There are two unique bisphosphonate ligands and four unique potassium cations in the structure, but the connectivity of the two individual [K2(LH3)­(H2O)6] components is virtually identical. The chain then propagates through μ-1κ2(O,O′)­:2κ3(O″,OH,COH) bisphosphonate bridging between successive potassium cations which are seven coordinate with the two additional coordinated water molecules (bridging to the second potassium cation). The metal–ligand connectivity and associated bond distances are shown in Figure S5.6 (the K–OH2 distances are in the range 2.733(1)–2.905(1) Å), with the next nearest K···O distance beyond 3.4 Å. A strong (1.75(2), 1.78(2) Å) O–H···O hydrogen bond interaction between the two phosphonate groups on the same LH3 2– ligand results in an eclipsed configuration, rather than staggered as in 6a, and thus plays no role in the supramolecular structure. Instead, the 3-D structure is dominated by water interactions with extensive O–H···O hydrogen bonding between coordinated water molecules as well as between water molecules and the phosphonate groups. These result in a distinctive bilayer structure with two parallel arrays of potassium polyhedra, sandwiched between compact regions containing the alkyl-ammonium groups (see a). In the latter, there is the usual head-to-tail arrangement of pairs of the bisphosphonate ligands, supported by further O–H···O (water/phosphonate) hydrogen bonding. However, the 4-ammoniobutylidene chains are not orientated perpendicular to the coordination polymer chain, but protrude more sideways, while maintaining the R 2 2(16) ring motif, with the ammonium groups now bridging between the metal-phosphonate layers.

In this case the polymer chain is comprised of pairs of edge-shared potassium polyhedra where the bisphosphonate ligand is bound to one potassium cation only, the second potassium cation being fully coordinated by six water molecules, two of which are bridging (b). There are two unique bisphosphonate ligands and four unique potassium cations in the structure, but the connectivity of the two individual [K2(LH3)(H2O)6] components is virtually identical. The chain then propagates through μ-1κ2(O,O'):2κ3(O",OH,COH) bisphosphonate bridging between successive potassium cations which are seven coordinate with the two additional coordinated water molecules (bridging to the second potassium cation). The metal-ligand connectivity and associated bond distances are shown in Figure S5.6 (the K-OH2 distances are in the range 2.733(1)-2.905(1) Å), with the next nearest K⋅⋅⋅O distance beyond 3.4 Å. A strong (1.75(2), 1.78(2) Å) O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bond interaction between the two phosphonate groups on the same LH3 2- ligand results in an eclipsed configuration, rather than staggered as in 6a, and thus plays no role in the supramolecular structure. Instead, the 3-D structure is dominated by water interactions with extensive O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding between coordinated water molecules as well as between water molecules and the phosphonate groups. These result in a distinctive bilayer structure with two parallel arrays of potassium polyhedra, sandwiched between compact regions containing the alkyl-ammonium groups (see a). In the latter, there is the usual head-to-tail arrangement of pairs of the bisphosphonate ligands, supported by further O-H⋅⋅⋅O (water/phosphonate) hydrogen bonding. However, the 4-ammoniobutylidene chains are not orientated perpendicular to the coordination polymer chain, but protrude more sideways, while maintaining the R 2 2(16) ring motif, with the ammonium groups now bridging between the metal-phosphonate layers.

elements.content: The M2(LH3) complexes of the larger Rb+ cations each exhibit 2-D sheet coordination polymer structures. In comparison with those of the M­(LH4) complexes (above), the structures show considerably more complexity with a significant structural influence from the large number of coordinated water molecules. The structure of 8a is shown in a polyhedral representation in a and comprises layers of 2-D coordination polymer sheets parallel to the ac plane. The complex 2-D sheets can be deconvoluted into two substructures; (A) chains of [Rb­(LH3)­(H2O)­(μ-H2O)2] units parallel to the a axis and containing solely Rb(1) (b) and (B) a central square grid composed of Rb(2) centers each connected by four bridging water molecules [Rb­(μ-H2O)4] (c). The chain substructure A is similar to 7b above, with adjacent metal centers bridged by 1κ2(O,O′)­:2κ2(OH,COH) bisphosphonate ligands. There are also two coordinated water molecules, O(9) and O(11) that bridge to Rb(2), as well as a terminal water molecule, O(8), giving overall a coordination number of seven. The central square grid substructure B (c) has eight coordinate Rb(2) centers bound to six water molecules, one terminal, O(10) and five bridging, O(9), O(11)/O(11′) and O(12)/O(12′). Additionally there are two unidentate Rb–OPO2 interactions O(1) and O(3) from the LH3 2– ligand. The chain substructure A lies alternately above and below the plane of the central grid, and along the direction of the a axis, and is connected to B through four points O(1), O(3), O(9) and O(11). The water molecule O(11) is μ3-bridging to one Rb(1) and two Rb(2) centers. The overall metal-bisphosphonate ligand connectivity and associated bond distances are shown in Figure S5.7. The Rb–OH2 distances are in the range 2.907(3)–3.303(4) Å for Rb(1) and 2.862(4)–3.288(4) Å for Rb(2). There are three additional long (>3.4 Å) interactions for Rb(1), two involving (nonbridging) PO3 2– oxygen atoms (Figure S5.7) and one water molecule, O(10), but these are not included in the bonding description. As with 7b above, O–H···O (water/phosphonate and water/water) hydrogen bonding dominates the 3-D supramolecular architecture, including water molecules O(12) and O(13) which link the bisphosphonate ligands along the chain in substructure A (b), and O(9), O(10), and O(11) which form short chains within the substructure B. In the interlayer regions of the structure, pairs of LH3 2– ligands and two of the lattice water molecules form a hydrogen bonded double-ring motif.

Additionally there are two unidentate Rb-OPO2 interactions O(1) and O(3) from the LH3 2- ligand. elements.content: The second Rb2(LH3) complex 8b contains fewer coordinated water molecules than 8a and has a complex structure comprising undulating 2-D coordination polymer sheets lying parallel to the ac plane (a). These sheets stack along the b axis though a variety of hydrogen bond interactions. There are two unique LH3 2– bisphosphonate ligands and four unique Rb+ centers arranged into two substructures which alternate throughout the 2-D sheet (b,c). Substructure A comprises a chain of Rb­(LH3)­(H2O)2 units in which successive eight-coordinate Rb(1) centers are bridged by 1κ2(O,O′)­:2κ2(O″,COH) bisphosphonate ligands (b). Two such chains are linked into a double strand through a centrosymmetric Rb2(μ-OH2)2 bridge, O(16), with additional support from a unidentate phosphonate group, O(5) (c). There is also a further coordinated water molecule, O(15) which bridges to Rb(2). Overall the bisphosphonate ligand bridges four metal centers (Figure S5.8) through an additional κ2(O,O″) ligand interaction to Rb(2). The substructure is reinforced by O–H···O (water/phosphonate) hydrogen bonds involving the coordinated water molecule O(16), which links the bisphosphonate ligands within the double-stranded chain in a R 4 4(16) ring motif. The second substructure B (c) is a centrosymmetric planar array of six Rb+ cations, involving Rb(2), Rb(3), and Rb(4) and two of the second bisphosphonate ligands. One of the phosphonate groups of the ligand spans a square of four metal centers through two oxygen atoms O(8), bridging Rb(2) and Rb(4), and O(10), bridging the centrosymmetric pair of Rb(3) centers. The C–OH group from the LH3 2– ligand also binds to Rb(4). The metals are further connected by bridging water molecules O(17) and O(18) between Rb(2) and Rb(4), and O(19) between Rb(2) and Rb(3), and there are two terminal water molecules bound to each Rb(3). The resulting coordination numbers are seven for Rb(2), six for Rb(3), and eight for Rb(4), with one longer (>3.4 Å) Rb–O distance for each metal center not considered in the bonding description. The Rb–OH2 distances are in the relatively narrow ranges of 3.057(8)–3.130(8) Å for Rb(1), 2.923(7)–3.032(9) Å for Rb(2), 2.806(7)–3.086(8) Å for Rb(3), and 2.915(6)–3.254(7) Å for Rb(4). Overall the second bisphosphonate ligand bridges six metal centers with an additional κ3(O,O′,O″) interaction to Rb(4) from a neighboring sheet substructure (Rb4vi in Figure S5.8). Within the substructure B, centrosymmetric pairs of the LH3 2– ligands are also linked through O–H···O hydrogen bonds, involving water molecule O(20), in a simple R 4 4(12) ring motif. The two substructures assemble into the 2-D coordination polymer like a louvered panel, with pairs of the double-stranded chain substructures sandwiching a set of canted parallel sheet substructures. Within this array, there is extensive water/phosphonate hydrogen bonding between the two substructures. Each layer is assembled into a 3-D supramolecular structure through N–H···O hydrogen bonds between the ammonium cations and phosphonate groups of a subsequent 2-D layer, with pairs of LH3 2– ligands forming the typical head to tail R 2 2(16) ring motif.

elements.content: The structure of the Cs complex 9a is similar to that of 8b above, although the composition of 9a has one additional coordinated water molecule. As with the analogous cesium complex 3b above, there are several Cs–O distances ca. 3.7 Å, and these are not considered significant coordinative interactions and are not discussed further in this and in the following structure 9b. Complex 9a presents as an undulating 2-D coordination polymer sheet parallel to the ac plane and stacking along the b axis through hydrogen bonding (a). As with 8b above, there are two unique ligands and four unique cesium cations, and the structure can be viewed similarly as a combination of two substructures. The first component (A) is a ladder-like coordination polymer comprising Cs­(LH3)­(μ-H2O)2­(H2O) repeat units propagating along the a axis with adjacent Cs(1) cations bridged by a 1κ2(O,O′)­:2κ3(O″,OH,COH) bisphosphonate ligand (b). Two chains are bridged through the one oxygen atom O(6) of a phosphonate group binding to a further symmetry generated Cs(1) center forming a centrosymmetric Cs2(μ-OPO2R)2 bridge (c). The ladder-like chains are connected to the substructure B (see below) through two of the three coordinated water molecules O(16) and O(17) bridging to the Cs(2), along with a single phosphonate oxygen atom O(4) which bridges Cs(2) and Cs(4). Overall, the first bisphosphonate ligand bridges four metal centers (Figure S5.9) and Cs(1) is nine-coordinate. Substructure A is further supported by a number of O–H···O hydrogen bonds, involving the coordinated water molecules O(15), O(16), and O(17) and the lattice water molecule O(25), which link pairs of the LH3 2– ligands in two perpendicular ring motifs, R 6 6(20) and R 5 5(18). The second substructure component (B) comprises six coplanar cesium cations and two bisphosphonate ligands in a centrosymmetric array. At the core is a Cs2(μ-H2O)2 unit involving two six-coordinate Cs(3) centers bridged by two water molecules, O(19) and symmetry generated O(19)i, and further bound to two oxygen atoms O(9) and O(10) from discrete bisphosphonate ligands, and two water molecules, O(20) bridging to Cs(2) and O(21) (c). The bisphosphonate ligand bridges Cs(2), Cs(3), and Cs(4) through a single oxygen atom, O(10), of one phosphonate group, with the second phosphonate having a κ2(O,O) interaction with Cs(4). There is also an additional κ2(OH,COH) to a Cs(4) center from a neighboring sheet substructure. The resulting coordination numbers are six for Cs(2), six for Cs(3), and nine for Cs(4), and the second bisphosphonate ligand bridges five metal centers (Figure S5.9). There is extensive O–H···O (water/phosphonate) hydrogen bonding involving the coordinated water molecules O(18), O(19), and O­(2O) and the lattice water molecule, O(24) within the substructure. Similar to 8b above, the overall 2-D coordination polymer assembles with alternating arrays of parallel canted sheet substructures sandwiched between two ladder substructures. Each layer is bridged by N–H···O (ammonium/phosphonate) hydrogen bonding, supported by head-to-tail pairing of the LH3 2– ligands in the R 2 2(16) ring motif and additionaly O–H···O (water/phosphonate) hydrogen bonding, involving water molecules O(21) and O(23), resulting in a 3-D supramolecular structure.

elements.content: The structure of 9b is also a 2-D coordination polymer (a) but is less complex than 9a (above) and comprises a single unique LH3 2– ligand, two Cs+ cations, and four coordinated water molecules. The primary substructure (b) can be described as a chain of Cs­(LH3) units in which successive Cs(1) centers are linked by a bisphosphonate ligand with μ-1κ3(O,O′,O″)­:2κ3(O‴,OH,COH) coordination. In addition, there are two water molecules, O(8) and O(11) bound to Cs(1) which is eight coordinate. In between two such chains, seven-coordinate Cs(2) centers are bound via a κ2(O,O′) phosphonate group from one chain and two unidentate phosphonate groups from the other chain as well as to three water molecules, O(9), O(10), and O(11) (c). Thus, O(4) and O(6) are μ3-bridging and the bisphosphonate ligand bridges five metal centers overall (Figure S5.10). Two of the three water molecules, O(9) and O(10) are terminal, with the third water molecule, (O11), bridging to Cs(1) from a neighboring substructure, resulting in the 2-D layer shown in a. The Cs–OH2 distances are 2.945(2) and 3.155(3) Å for Cs(1) and 3.037(2)–3.262(3) Å for Cs(2). The coordination interactions within these layers are further supported by O–H···O (water/phosphonate) hydrogen bonds, involving the water molecules O(9) or O(11), forming an interconnected network of centrosymmetric R 4 4(12) and R 6 6(16) ring motifs. Neighboring layers are assembled into a 3-D supramolecular structure through hydrogen bonding of head to tail pairs of LH3 2– ligands and water molecules, O(10), in a double ring motif as also observed in 8a above, as well as by O–H···O (water/phosphonate) hydrogen bond bridges involving the water molecule O(8).

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized and crystallized by a range of varying conditions three series of new group 1 metal complexes of the commercially utilized bisphosphonic acid, alendronic acid. These apparently simple acid–base systems revealed a deep and versatile complexity, in particular with the larger K+, Rb+, and Cs+ cations, with a number of differing synthetic outcomes as well as some considerable structural variety, even within a particular metal/bisphosphonate system. For the M­(LH4) complexes the presence of two strong P–OH hydrogen bond donors are a significant structural feature which effectively competed with the coordinative metal-bisphosphonate bonding. This was elegantly illustrated by the observation of a consistent supramolecular bisphosphonate framework for [Na­(LH4)­(H2O)]­·2­(H2O) and [M­(LH4)­(H2O)]­·H2O M = Rb 2b (phase II), M = Cs 3b (phase II), with the M+ cations situated to best suit their respective coordination requirements. By contrast, P–OH interactions play little role in the structures of the M2(LH3) complexes which are influenced by the higher numbers of coordinated water molecules. Even so, chain type {M­(LH3)} n substructures incorporating μ-1κ2(O,O′)­:2κ3(O″,O‴,O⁗) bisphosphonate ligands were apparent in each of the M2(LH3) structures. Additional M­(OH2) m moieties are incorporated in various ways. Indeed, complexes with the highest number of water molecules, for example, 7b, are close to a being a fully separated ion pair complex. The large number of water molecules in these structures also results in a complex network of hydrogen bond interactions which support the 3-D network, often with recurring ring motifs. However, a consistent feature of both the M­(LH4) and M2L­(H3) structures was the head to tail pairing of two bisphosphonate ligands. This strong supramolecular synthon effectively pillared the M­(LH4) complexes generating distinct metal-phosphonate and alkyl chain layers. Overall, the metal bonding of the bisphosphonate ligands varied from simple bridging of two metal centers to more complex modes involving up to six metal centers and all seven oxygen donor atoms, confirming their exceptional coordinating ability.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have synthesized and crystallized by a range of varying conditions three series of new group 1 metal complexes of the commercially utilized bisphosphonic acid, alendronic acid. These apparently simple acid-base systems revealed a deep and versatile complexity, in particular with the larger K+, Rb+, and Cs+ cations, with a number of differing synthetic outcomes as well as some considerable structural variety, even within a particular metal/bisphosphonate system. For the M(LH4) complexes the presence of two strong P-OH hydrogen bond donors are a significant structural feature which effectively competed with the coordinative metal-bisphosphonate bonding. This was elegantly illustrated by the observation of a consistent supramolecular bisphosphonate framework for [Na(LH4)(H2O)]⋅2(H2O) and [M(LH4)(H2O)]⋅H2O M = Rb 2b (phase II), M = Cs 3b (phase II), with the M+ cations situated to best suit their respective coordination requirements. By contrast, P-OH interactions play little role in the structures of the M2(LH3) complexes which are influenced by the higher numbers of coordinated water molecules. Even so, chain type {M(LH3)} n  substructures incorporating μ-1κ2(O,O'):2κ3(O",O‴,O⁗) bisphosphonate ligands were apparent in each of the M2(LH3) structures. Additional M(OH2) m  moieties are incorporated in various ways. Indeed, complexes with the highest number of water molecules, for example, 7b, are close to a being a fully separated ion pair complex. The large number of water molecules in these structures also results in a complex network of hydrogen bond interactions which support the 3-D network, often with recurring ring motifs. However, a consistent feature of both the M(LH4) and M2L(H3) structures was the head to tail pairing of two bisphosphonate ligands. This strong supramolecular synthon effectively pillared the M(LH4) complexes generating distinct metal-phosphonate and alkyl chain layers. Overall, the metal bonding of the bisphosphonate ligands varied from simple bridging of two metal centers to more complex modes involving up to six metal centers and all seven oxygen donor atoms, confirming their exceptional coordinating ability.
